div.head: Title
div.p: In the presentation copy bound in MS XI, Ruskin wrote the title as “THE SUN”; and in MS III, he wrote the title in capitals without emphasis, as “THE SUN”.
See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: In MS XI, “The Sun” is printed by Ruskin in pencil as a presentation copy for New Yearʼs 1828, followed on the same sheet by “Glenfarg” and “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”).

In MS III, a Red Book devoted initially “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2, “The Sun” appears as the third poem in the MS III Second Poetry Anthology, followed by “Glenfarg” and “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”) as the fourth poem—the same sequence in which they are printed in the presentation copy. “The Sun” is preceded in the anthology by the New Yearʼs poem for 1827, “Time: Blank Verse”; and both are preceded by the first poem in the anthology, “The Constellations”.
Facsimiles by permission of John Ruskin Collection, General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Transcriptions of texts and commentary © David C. Hanson.

div.head: Date
div.p: Dated by Ruskin in a presentation copy, MS XI. In this copy, the poem is followed by “Glenfarg” and “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”), with the date placed between them in Ruskinʼs hand.

div.head: Composition & Publication
div.p: Published with omissions in Poems (4o, 1891), 1:5–6; and Poems (8o, 1891), 1:5–6; and in full in Ruskin, Works, 2:260–61.

div.head: Sources
div.p:
With “mamma beside me” walking in the garden, Ruskinʼs praise condenses Adam and Eveʼs morning hymn in book 5 of Paradise Lost, “These are thy glorious works, Parent of good”. Ruskin relies on Miltonʼs organizing trope of the sunʼs course from dawn to noon to sunset, and he borrows some diction such as invoking the sun to “disperse” the night.
Thou Sun, of this great World both Eye and Soul,
Acknowledge him thy Greater, sound his praise
In thy eternal course, both when thou climbʼst,
And when high Noon hast gainʼd, and when thou fallʼst.
Moon, that now meetʼst the orient Sun, now fliʼst
With the fixt Stars, fixt in thir Orb that flies,
And yee five other wandʼring Fires that move
In mystic Dance not without Song, resound
His praise, who out of Darkness callʼd up Light.
Air, and ye Elements the eldest birth
Of Natureʼs Womb, that in quaternion run
Perpetual Circle, multiform, and mix
And nourish all things, let your ceaseless change
Vary to our great Maker still new praise.
Ye Mists and Exhalations that now rise
From Hill or steaming Lake, dusky or gray,
Till the Sun paint your fleecy skirts with Gold,
In honor to the Worldʼs great Author rise,
Whether to deck with Clouds thʼ uncolorʼd sky,
Or wet the thirsty Earth with falling showers,
Rising or falling still advance his praise.
His praise ye Winds, that from four Quarters blow,
Breathe soft or loud; and wave your tops, ye Pines,
With every Plant, in sign of Worship wave.
Fountains and yee, that warble, as ye flow,
Melodious murmurs, warbling tune his praise.
Join voices all ye living Souls; ye Birds,
That singing up to Heaven Gate ascend,
Bear on your wings and in your notes his praise;
Yee that in Waters glide, and yee that walk
The Earth, and stately tread, or lowly creep;
Witness if I be silent, Morn or Even,
To Hill, or Valley, Fountain, or fresh shade
Made vocal by my Song, and taught his praise.
Hail universal Lord, be bounteous still
To give us only good; and if the night
Have gatherʼd aught of evil or concealʼd,
Disperse it, as now light dispels the dark.
(Milton, Paradise Lost, 5:171-208, in Complete Poems and Major Prose, ed. Hughes, 306-7)

In MS III, “The Sun” shares an interest in constellations with “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol 2”, and with “The Constellations: Northern, Some of the Zodiac, and Some of the Southern”. See also “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Glen of Glenfarg thy beauteous rill”).
